intro: Cinchona carabayensis var. lanceolata, commonly known as the Peruvian bark or quina, is a species native to the Andean regions of South America. It is a member of the Rubiaceae family and is characterized by its lance-shaped leaves and clusters of small, fragrant flowers. The plant produces red, elongated berries that contain the medicinal alkaloid quinine, historically used to treat malaria. It thrives in tropical and subtropical climates with high humidity and well-drained soil. Due to its medicinal value, it has been cultivated in various parts of the world for centuries.
